Chris,

The existence of the Composite pattern in the Test/TestCase/TestSuite troika
caused us problems. It was difficult to explain and it made writing test
runners more difficult. One particularly vexing problem was re-running
single tests while making sure all the TestDecorators and TestSuite
subclasses higher in the test tree were run correctly. Instead, the JUnit 4
runner takes a flat array of test classes. This is easier to explain and
easier to implement correctly.

Now we are encountering just how heavily used TestDecorator and TestSuite
subclassing are used in JUnit extensions. Our challenge is to provide
equivalently powerful extension mechanisms while retaining the simplicity of
the new approach. One such is the @BeforeClass/@AfterClass annotations. If
we can't provide enough extensibility with two-level suite specifications,
we will go back to recursive test suites. In the meantime, our new runner
should run pre-JUnit 4-style tests correctly.

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute
